document.masterDocTitle: Cybaeus (Araneae: Cybaeidae) in the Nearctic: the devius and tardatus species groups of the Californian clade

.

of
Namopsilus pletus
.
Los Angeles County , Claremont ,
iv.1913
, R.V. Chamberlin ( MCZ ), examined
.

Other material examined.
U.S.A. :
California
:
Los Angeles. 1♂ , Claremont , no date, no collector ( MCZ ); 1♀ Pasadena,
vi.1945
, S.C. Bishop ( AMNH )
.

Diagnosis. The male of
C. tardatus
is readily diagnosed by the form of the proximal and distal arms of the tegular apophysis ( Figs 48 , 60 ); these characteristics are discussed under the diagnosis of
C. piazzai
spec. nov.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 50–54.
Cybaeus spp.
, females, copulatory organ (50–51
C. tardatus
, holotype of
Namopsilus pletus
; 52–54
C. topanga
spec. nov.
, from San Ysidro, California). 50–51, 53–54 Vulva (50, 53 ventral, 51, 54 dorsal). 52 Atrium (anterior portion), ventral. BG—Bennett’s gland, CD—copulatory duct, SS—stalk of spermatheca.

FIGURES 55–58.
Cybaeus topanga
spec. nov.
, holotype male, left palpus. 55–56 Patella and tibia (55 retrolateral, 56 dorsal). 57–58 Genital bulb (57 ventral, 58 retrolateral). E—embolus, PA—proximal arm of tegular apophysis, PTA—patellar apophysis, RTA—retrolateral tibial apophysis. Unlabelled arrow indicates concave distal prolateral margin of DA.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distinguishing the females of
C. orarius
spec. nov.
and
C. tardatus
is discussed under the diagnosis of the former. From the other females in the
tardatus
species group with rounded spermathecal bases (
C. piazzai
spec. nov.
,
C. topanga
spec. nov.
) the female of
C. tardatus
is distinguished by the nearly parallel-sided atrial area, the copulatory ducts contiguous over much of their length, as well as the general simplicity of the vulval ducts ( Figs 50–51 ) ( versus atrial area inverted vase-shaped with sides diverging posteriorly [ Figs 42 , 52–53 ], copulatory ducts non-contiguous [ Fig. 43 ] or contiguous only along anterior-most section [ Figs 42 , 54 ], and vulval ducts complex [ Figs 42–43, 45 , 53–54 ] in
C. piazzai
spec. nov.
and
C. topanga
spec. nov.
).
Description. Ventral tibia I macrosetae: 2-1p-2-1p-2. Femora and tibia lightly banded.

Male :
(n=2). About 40 peg setae on strongly anteriorly directed patellar apophysis ( Fig. 47 ). Retrolateral tibial apophysis about 2/3 the length of the tibia, not extending to anterior margin of tibia ( Fig. 46 ).
Measurements (n=2). CL 3.2, 3.3; CW 2.50, 2.50; SL 1.55, 1.53; SW 1.48, 1.48. Holotype listed first.

Female :
(n=2). Atrium ( Fig. 50 ) with area between atrial openings slightly raised and convex, largely parallelsided but slightly widening posteriorly. Vulva ( Figs 50–51 ) with copulatory ducts opening into atria from midline of vulva, well sclerotized posteriorly, less so anteriorly; heads of spermathecae undifferentiated from adjacent ducts ( i.e. not distinct lobes), located near posterior margin of vulva, visible in dorsal view; spermathecal stalks short, thick walled; Bennett’s glands visible in dorsal view on small, thick walled, rounded spermathecal bases.

Measurements (n=2). CL 2.9, 3.3; CW 2.03, 2.38; SL 1.33, 1.48; SW 1.30, 1.48. Holotype of
N. pletus
listed second.

Distribution. ( Fig. 62 ). Los Angeles County, California . Male specimens listed in Chamberlin and Ivie (1932) from Ensenada, Baja California have not been found. We consider Ensenada to be outside the range of
C. tardatus
and have not included that locality in the distribution map.
